description: Borrowed from Latin neglēctus, perfect passive participle of neglegō (“make light of, disregard, not to pick up”), a variant of neclegō, itself from nec (“not”) + legō (“pick up, select”). Recorded since 1529, as noun since 1588.

verbs.description: neglect (third-person singular simple present neglects, present participle neglecting, simple past and past participle neglected)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To fail to care for or attend to something.
examples: to neglect duty or business;  to neglect to pay debts

entries.meaning: (transitive) To omit to notice; to forbear to treat with attention or respect; to slight.
(transitive) To fail to do or carry out something due to oversight or carelessness.
(transitive, mathematics) To ignore for the sake of simplifying calculations without significantly affecting accuracy.
examples: We can neglect this term, as it approaches zero in the limit anyway.
This problem says to neglect air resistance.
